stop.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to not continue, or to make someone or something not continue
stop.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: By midday the rain had stopped.
This is where the path stops.
The doctor advised me to stop the medication.
People are fighting to stop the destruction of the rain forests.
stop.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: if you stop doing something, you do not continue to do it
stop.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: What time do you stop work?
I’ve been smoking for over ten years, and I can’t stop.
Right, stop what you’re doing and come over here.
Come on, you two! Stop it!
I stopped digging and looked at him.
stop.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to prevent someone from doing something or something from happening
stop.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The government tried to stop publication of the book.
I’m leaving now, and you can’t stop me.
There’s nothing to stop you applying for the job yourself.
there’s nothing to stop somebody (from) doing something
Lay the carpet on paper to stop it sticking to the floor.
The rain didn’t stop us from enjoying the trip.
She grabbed the rail to stop herself from falling.
stop.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to not walk, move, or travel anymore, or to make someone or something do this
stop.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to pause in an activity, journey etc in order to do something before you continue
stop.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: It’s time we stopped to think about our next move.
We stopped for a drink on the way home.
I stopped to tie my shoe.
stop.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to stay somewhere for a short time, especially at someone’s house
stop.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: I won’t sit down – I’m not stopping.
Will you stop for a cup of tea?
stop.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: if you stop an amount of money, you prevent it from being paid to someone
stop.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Dad threatened to stop my pocket money.
I phoned the bank and asked them to stop the cheque (=not pay a cheque that I had written).
My mother called the bank to stop payment on the check.
£200 will be stopped from your wages next month to pay for the damage.
stop.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to block a hole or pipe so that water, smoke etc cannot go through it
stop.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Patterns with stop
stop.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: If you stop doing something, you do not continue doing it
Stop writing and put your pens down
Stop to write and put your pens down
stop.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: If you stop to do something, you stop moving or stop what you are doing for a short time, in order to do something else
She stopped to look at the map
stop.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: Stop belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
stop.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: In this sentence, ‘the car’ is the object of stop
stop.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4]: In this sentence, ‘the car’ is the subject of stop
stop.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: to stop doing something
to not do something any longer
I wish she would stop talking.
He waited for them to stop.
quit
to stop doing something
She needs to quit complaining about her life.
It’s too late for him to quit now.
give something up
to stop doing something, especially something that you have been doing for a long time
It’s so hard to give up smoking.
She wants to give up her job.
I’ve given up trying to tell my son to clean his room.
pack something in
to stop doing something, especially because you feel tired or annoyed
Sometimes I feel like packing in my job and starting again somewhere else.
Pack it in, will you! (=used when telling someone to stop doing something, because they are annoying you)
pull out of something
to stop taking part in something that you have agreed to take part in
The unions have pulled out of the negotiations.
The US decided to pull out of the competition.
cease
to stop doing something
The company has decided to cease production of its film cameras.
The US government ceased talks with North Korea.
to stop for a short time
to stop for a short time
Shall we stop for coffee now?
I stopped to have a look at the map.
pause
to stop speaking or doing something for a short time before starting again
He paused for a moment to consider the question.
‘I think it’s going to rain, ’ she said, pausing to look up at the sky.
have/take a break
to stop working, studying, or driving for a short time in order to rest
Okay, everyone. Take a ten-minute break.
If you’re feeling tired, you should have a break.
to stop working, studying etc in order to rest or eat something – used about a group of people who are doing something together
After a couple of hours the committee broke for lunch.
to stop happening
to stop happening
The noise suddenly stopped.
We waited for the rain to stop.
come to an end
to stop – used about something that has continued for a long time
The war finally came to an end in 1918.
wear off
to gradually stop – used about a pain, a feeling, or the effects of something
The pain will soon wear off.
The excitement was beginning to wear off.
The anaesthetic took a long time to wear off.
peter out
to gradually stop happening or existing
The campaign petered out after only a few weeks.
cease
to stop
The fighting has ceased.
Production at the factory has ceased.
to stop moving
to stop moving
Can we stop soon? I’m tired.
The bus stops right in front of the hotel.
come to a halt
to move more slowly and then stop – used about a vehicle
The train slowly came to a halt just outside the station.
The plane came to a halt less than twenty yards away from the limousines.
pull over
to move to the side of the road and stop – used about a vehicle or its driver
The bus pulled over to the side of the road, with smoke coming out of its engine.
The police officer was waving at him to pull over.
pull up
to stop close to something – used about a vehicle or its driver
The taxi pulled up outside her house.
He pulled up next to our car.
come to a standstill
to go slower and then stop moving completely
The road was blocked by an accident, and the traffic quickly came to a standstill.
stop.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a time or place when you stop during a journey for a short time
stop.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: We’ll make a stop at the foot of the hill.
The trip includes an overnight stop in London.
stop.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a place where a bus or train regularly stops for people to get on and off
stop.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Our next stop will be York.
This is your stop, isn’t it?
stop.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: the action or fact of telling your bank not to pay an amount of money to someone
stop.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: I put a stop on that check to the store.
stop.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a handle that you push in or out on an organ to control the amount of sound it produces
stop.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a consonant sound, like /p/ or /k/, that you make by stopping the flow of air completely and then suddenly letting it out of your mouth
stop.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to prevent someone from doing something or something from happening
stop.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The government should intervene to stop the takeover.
How can we stop the decline in sales?
This latest crisis did not stop the Bank of France cutting its key interest rates.
News of the takeover immediately stopped the company’s shares from sliding.
stop.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to no longer continue to do something
stop.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: What time do you stop work?
Lack of funds forced us to stop production.
Japan’s four leading brokerages agreed to stop issuing new shares for a month.
You can stop paying premiums at any time.
stop.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to tell a bank not to pay a cheque you have written
stop.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Staff are failing to charge customers for such services as stopping cheques or returning standing orders unpaid.
stop.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: to prevent money from being paid after you agree to pay it
stop.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: Money for breakages will be stopped from your wages.
stop.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Production came to a virtual stop during the two-week strike.
stop.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to prevent something from continuing or happening
stop.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: These quotas put a stop to further export growth.
stop.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: to tell a bank not to pay a cheque you have written
